title: 109_hr2936
content: The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" requires group health plans to cover second opinions under the Public Health Service Act. The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" mandates group health plans to provide or authorize second opinions by qualified healthcare professionals upon request from participants, beneficiaries, or enrollees questioning surgical procedures, diagnoses, or treatment plans for serious conditions. The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" requires group health plans to offer second opinions by qualified healthcare professionals when a diagnosis or treatment plan is not improving within a reasonable time, the individual requests a second opinion, or has serious concerns about the initial diagnosis or plan of care. An appropriately qualified health care professional is defined as a primary care physician or specialist with relevant clinical background and expertise. The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" mandates timely provision of second opinions for participants facing imminent health threats, with a maximum 72-hour response time. Plans must establish response timelines for emergency cases within 90 days of enactment, updated within 30 days of any changes. The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" requires timely provision of second opinions for participants facing health threats. Participants are responsible for copayments for second opinions, and can choose their healthcare professional for primary care requests or specialists within the network. The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" mandates timely second opinions for participants. If a specialist outside the network is needed, the plan must cover the cost or negotiate fees. If no in-network provider meets standards, an outside opinion can be authorized. Travel costs are not covered by the plan. The plan or issuer must require a second opinion health professional to provide a consultation report with recommended procedures. If a request for a second opinion is denied, the participant must be informed in writing of the reasons and their right to file a grievance. Services must be obtained from participating providers unless authorized otherwise. The plan or issuer may limit referrals to its network of providers if there is a participating plan provider who meets the standard specified. Exemption applies to health care service plan contracts that provide benefits through preferred provider contracting arrangements. Notice requirements under ERISA must be followed by group health plans regarding the provisions of this section. Amendments to ERISA include referencing sections 2704 and 2707. ERISA amendments include adding a new section to Subpart B of part 7 of title I of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, referencing sections 2704 and 2707. "SEC. 714. COVERAGE OF SECOND OPINIONS." The provisions of section 2707 apply to group health plans and insurance coverage. Notice of requirements must be provided within 60 days of the first plan year. Amendments are made to sections 731(c) and 732(a) of the Act. Amendments are made to the table of contents in section 1 of the Act by inserting a new item after section 713. Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code and the Public Health Service Act to include coverage of second opinions in healthcare. The requirements of section 2707 of the Public Health Service Act apply to this new coverage. The provisions of section 2707 apply to health insurance coverage in the individual market, with notice requirements similar to group health plans. Amendments also include coverage of second opinions in healthcare. Effective dates vary for group and individual health plans. Individual health insurance coverage amendments apply to plans in the individual market. There is an exception for group health plans under collective bargaining agreements ratified before the enactment of the Act. Amendments do not apply to plan years before the termination of collective bargaining agreements or January 1, 2006. The Secretary of Labor, Treasury, and Health and Human Services must coordinate to ensure regulations and enforcement policies are consistent and avoid duplication of efforts under the Act.
